nodes.text: IT projects are riskier than managers typically realize because a disproportionate number produce extreme cost and schedule overruns (Black Swans) that threaten jobs and firms
We conducted the largest global empirical study of IT change initiatives, examining a sample of 1,471 projects across project types and organizations
The projects in the sample had an average cost of $167 million and ranged up to $33 billion
When comparing budgets and estimated benefits with actual costs and results we found a fat tail distribution in cost overruns
Average cost overrun across the sample was 27%, but this average masks a large number of extreme overages
One in six projects were Black Swans with average cost overruns of 200% and schedule overruns of almost 70%
The sample was composed largely of public agencies (92%) and US projects (83%), but researchers found little difference in outcomes when including private and European projects
Focusing on averages instead of the damaging outliers causes managers and consultants to miss the true IT project risk
Mismanaged and out-of-control IT projects have ended executives careers and caused corporate failure and large economic losses
Levi Strauss: a planned sub-5 million dollar SAP migration produced system failures, a $192.5 million charge, and the CIO s resignation
Kmart and Auto Windscreens experienced IT project problems that contributed to bankruptcy or failure; Toll Collect and Hong Kong airport problems led to multi billion dollar losses
To avoid IT Black Swans companies should perform a stress test and adopt specific mitigation practices
Complex product development projects can fail when teams use inconsistent software versions or lack understanding of software integration, as in Airbus A380 wiring and configuration issues
The recommended stress test asks whether the company can absorb a 400% cost overrun with only 25% to 50% of projected benefits, and whether 15% of medium projects might overrun by 200%

Mitigation practices include breaking big projects into smaller modules, contingency planning, preventing team turnover, framing initiatives as business efforts, and using best forecasting techniques such as reference class forecasting
CEOs and top managers must be acutely aware of IT risks and oversee major technology projects because these projects now touch many aspects of organizations

Emirates NBD is a success case: after doubling project scope via a merger, schedule slipped only 7% and costs exceeded estimates by 18% when leaders resisted scope changes, modularized work, assembled the right team, prevented turnover, and focused on readiness to go live
